newsitem.title: USA: USWC spot gasoline edges up, distillates seen weak.
newsitem.headline: USWC spot gasoline edges up, distillates seen weak.

text.p: Spot markets for U.S. West Coast refined product were quiet late Friday, with gasoline prices edging up with the NYMEX, traders said.
Wholesale unleaded gasoline prices rose between 0.50 and 1.00 cent a gallon Friday, but talk was thin as traders left the market early for an industry function.
"There was a lack of participation in today's market," said a trader for a California refinery.
A moderate rise in NYMEX energy futures tugged up California spot prices, with crude oil for May delivery up 49 cents a barrel on heavy technical and refinery buying.
CARB cleaner-burning gasoline was pegged between 71 and 72 cents a gallon in Los Angeles, up 0.50 cents from Thursday.
Conventional gasoline in L.A. gained one cent ot 65.50/66.50 cents.
Despite a notional 0.50 cent rise, many sellers came into the market for "EPA," or low sulphur diesel. Traders said a surplus of the fuel would weaken prices short-term.
Jet fuel ended the day flat at 60.50/61.50 cents, but was seen weakening as talk of an arriving cargo, traders said.
